title: How to Make Apple Pie Flavored Syrup

steps.headline: Mix together all of the sugar with the cinnamon and nutmeg in the medium sized bowl.
Fill one of the large pots halfway with cider and pour in the apple juice to fill the pot three-fourths up.
steps.description: It's okay to eyeball the amount during the pouring process.

steps.headline: Pour in all of the sugar mixture and use the stirring spoon to blend it in.
Cook your apple mixture.
steps.description: Bring the pot to a rolling boil on high heat. Stir occasionally.

steps.headline: Once it’s boiling lower heat to its lowest level and let cook.
steps.description: Leave the lid on and cracked at the top.

steps.headline: Let it cook until the water level has dropped back to the one-fourth point.
steps.description: After it drops, refill the pot up to the halfway point using the apple cider. Then add in more apple juice to the three-fourths point and stir with the spoon until it’s well-blended again.

steps.headline: Repeat until all the apple cider is gone, which could take up to three or four hours.
Let the syrup cool for at least three hours, or until it’s around one hundred and twenty degrees Fahrenheit, so that it is still warm enough to pour into jars.
Put the jars in the second pot.
steps.description: Fill it halfway with tap water.

steps.headline: Warm the water up on the lowest setting of your stove until the water is the same temperature at the syrup.
steps.description: This will keep the glass from cracking from the temperature difference when you pour the syrup in.

steps.headline: Gently pour out the water and use tongs to take out the jars.
Put a funnel in one of the jars.
steps.description: Use the oven mitts to pick up the syrup pot and fill the jars to the top.

steps.headline: Screw on the lids and put the jars on a countertop to cool overnight.
steps.description: In the morning the apple pie syrup should have a clear, reddish-dark, amber-brown coloring.

steps.headline: Use it to drizzle over pancakes, waffles, and oatmeal or any other sweet treat your heart desires.

text: Mix together all of the sugar with the cinnamon and nutmeg in the medium sized bowl.  Fill one of the large pots halfway with cider and pour in the apple juice to fill the pot three-fourths up. It's okay to eyeball the amount during the pouring process. Pour in all of the sugar mixture and use the stirring spoon to blend it in.  Cook your apple mixture. Bring the pot to a rolling boil on high heat. Stir occasionally. Once it’s boiling lower heat to its lowest level and let cook. Leave the lid on and cracked at the top. Let it cook until the water level has dropped back to the one-fourth point. After it drops, refill the pot up to the halfway point using the apple cider. Then add in more apple juice to the three-fourths point and stir with the spoon until it’s well-blended again. Repeat until all the apple cider is gone, which could take up to three or four hours.  Let the syrup cool for at least three hours, or until it’s around one hundred and twenty degrees Fahrenheit, so that it is still warm enough to pour into jars.  Put the jars in the second pot. Fill it halfway with tap water. Warm the water up on the lowest setting of your stove until the water is the same temperature at the syrup. This will keep the glass from cracking from the temperature difference when you pour the syrup in. Gently pour out the water and use tongs to take out the jars.  Put a funnel in one of the jars. Use the oven mitts to pick up the syrup pot and fill the jars to the top. Screw on the lids and put the jars on a countertop to cool overnight. In the morning the apple pie syrup should have a clear, reddish-dark, amber-brown coloring. Use it to drizzle over pancakes, waffles, and oatmeal or any other sweet treat your heart desires. Bacon is highly recommended.
